topics.title: The DMIS: Stages of Cultural Sensitivity

discovery.text: Most people are stuck at Minimization â€” 'We're all basically the same.' It feels inclusive but erases real differences.

climax.text: Integration, the final stage, means holding multiple cultural frames simultaneously â€” thinking and feeling in more.

hook.text: Geert Hofstede surveyed 116,000 IBM employees across 72 countries. He found that culture could be measured on six axes.

discovery.text: Each dimension is a spectrum. Every country scores differently, creating a unique cultural fingerprint.

climax.text: The safest cross-cultural humor targets universal human experiences â€” not specific groups, politics, or cultural habits.

hook.text: The 'thumbs up' means 'great' in the US. In parts of the Middle East, it's an obscene insult.

topics.title: Gift-Giving Etiquette: A Minefield of Meaning

hook.text: Give a clock in China and you've wished them death. Give white flowers in Japan and you've brought funeral vibes.

twist.text: The value matters too. Too expensive in Scandinavia is uncomfortable. Too cheap in the Middle East is insulting.

discovery.text: Unlike personality traits, CQ is learnable. Travel, immersion, diverse relationships, and cross-cultural training all.
